profile.name: Базовое сканирование
profile.description: Быстрое базовое сканирование без активного тестирования

alerts.description: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.
alerts.solution: For secure content, ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate". If an asset should be cached consider setting the directives "public, max-age, immutable".
alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives

alerts.description: The Content-Type header was either missing or empty.
alerts.solution: Ensure each page is setting the specific and appropriate content-type value for the content being delivered.
alerts.name: Content-Type Header Missing

alerts.description: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.
alerts.solution: For secure content, ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate". If an asset should be cached consider setting the directives "public, max-age, immutable".
alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.
alerts.name: Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.
alerts.name: Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.other:
User-controlled HTML attribute values were found. Try injecting special characters to see if XSS might be possible. The page at the following URL:

https://www.ptsecurity.com/ru-ru/products/?advertisingAgreements=on&agreements=on&clientId&companyAddress&companyName&email=zaproxy%40example.com&fio=ZAP&formId&inn&pageUrl&questions&source&tabId&title=Products

appears to include user input in:
a(n) [input] tag [value] attribute

The user input found was:
title=Products

The user-controlled value was:
products
alerts.description: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.
alerts.solution: Validate all input and sanitize output it before writing to any HTML attributes.
alerts.alert: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.other:
User-controlled HTML attribute values were found. Try injecting special characters to see if XSS might be possible. The page at the following URL:

https://www.ptsecurity.com/ru-ru/services/?advertisingAgreements=on&agreements=on&clientId&companyAddress&companyName&email=zaproxy%40example.com&fio=ZAP&formId&inn&pageUrl&questions&source&tabId&title=Services

appears to include user input in:
a(n) [input] tag [value] attribute

The user input found was:
title=Services

The user-controlled value was:
services
alerts.description: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.
alerts.solution: Validate all input and sanitize output it before writing to any HTML attributes.
alerts.alert: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Information in URL

alerts.solution: Review the source code of this page. Implement custom error pages. Consider implementing a mechanism to provide a unique error reference/identifier to the client (browser) while logging the details on the server side and not exposing them to the user.

alerts.description: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

alerts.other:
User-controlled HTML attribute values were found. Try injecting special characters to see if XSS might be possible. The page at the following URL:

https://www.ptsecurity.com/ru-ru/about/clients/?advertisingAgreements=on&agreements=on&clientId&companyAddress&companyName&email=zaproxy%40example.com&fio=ZAP&formId&inn&pageUrl&questions&source&tabId&title=%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8+%D0%BA%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B

appears to include user input in:
a(n) [meta] tag [content] attribute

The user input found was:
title=Наши клиенты

The user-controlled value was:
наши клиенты
alerts.description: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.
alerts.solution: Validate all input and sanitize output it before writing to any HTML attributes.
alerts.alert: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
